text: To whom is the Gospel of Luke addressed?
verseText: it seemed good to me also, having followed all things closely for some time past, to write an orderly account for you, most excellent Theophilus,

text: Luke's Gospel provides a detailed account of what event not found in Matthew or Mark?
options: The birth and childhood of John the Baptist and Jesus
verseText: (Luke chapters 1 and 2 contain unique details about the announcements, births, and early lives of both John the Baptist and Jesus).

text: Luke emphasizes Jesus' concern for which groups of people?
options: The poor, outcasts, women, Samaritans, Gentiles
verseText: (Luke highlights Jesus' compassion and ministry towards marginalized groups often overlooked in society).

text: Which famous parable, unique to Luke, tells of a son who squanders his inheritance but is welcomed back by his father?
options: The Parable of the Good Samaritan
The Parable of the Prodigal Son
verseText: And he said, “There was a man who had two sons. And the younger of them said to his father, ‘Father, give me the share of property that is coming to me.’ And he divided his property between them...

text: Luke's genealogy of Jesus (Luke 3) traces Jesus' ancestry back to whom?
verseText: ...the son of Enos, the son of Seth, the son of Adam, the son of God.

text: What other New Testament book did the author of Luke write?
verseText: In the first book, O Theophilus, I have dealt with all that Jesus began to do and teach,

text: In Luke 10, Jesus tells the Parable of the Good Samaritan in response to what question?
options: 'What must I do to be saved?'
verseText: But he, desiring to justify himself, said to Jesus, “And who is my neighbor?”

text: Luke's account of the Last Supper includes Jesus' words instituting the cup and bread, and also a prediction of betrayal and what dispute among the disciples?
options: Who would pay for the meal
Who was the greatest among them
verseText: A dispute also arose among them, as to which of them was to be regarded as the greatest.

text: On the road to Emmaus (Luke 24), the resurrected Jesus explains what to two disciples?
options: How the Scriptures (Old Testament) pointed to his suffering and glory
The structure of the early church
verseText: And beginning with Moses and all the Prophets, he interpreted to them in all the Scriptures the things concerning himself.

text: Luke often emphasizes the role of...
verseText: (Luke frequently mentions the Holy Spirit's activity and Jesus' or others' engagement in prayer).

text: Who was the angel that appeared to Zechariah and later to Mary?
verseText: And the angel answered him, “I am Gabriel. I stand in the presence of God...” ... In the sixth month the angel Gabriel was sent from God to a city of Galilee named Nazareth,

text: What sign was given to Zechariah because he doubted the angel's message about John's birth?
verseText: And behold, you will be silent and unable to speak until the day that these things take place, because you did not believe my words, which will be fulfilled in their time.”

text: What is the name of Mary's song of praise recorded in Luke 1?
verseText: And Mary said, “My soul magnifies the Lord, and my spirit rejoices in God my Savior...”

text: What is the name of Zechariah's prophecy/song after John the Baptist's birth (Luke 1)?
verseText: And his father Zechariah was filled with the Holy Spirit and prophesied, saying, “Blessed be the Lord God of Israel, for he has visited and redeemed his people...”

text: Why did Joseph and Mary travel to Bethlehem before Jesus' birth (Luke 2)?
options: To register for a census decreed by Caesar Augustus
verseText: In those days a decree went out from Caesar Augustus that all the world should be registered... And Joseph also went up from Galilee, from the town of Nazareth, to Judea, to the city of David, which is called Bethlehem, because he was of the house and lineage of David,

text: Who were the first people to be told about Jesus' birth by an angel, according to Luke 2?
verseText: And in the same region there were shepherds out in the field, keeping watch over their flock by night. And an angel of the Lord appeared to them...

text: Who were the two elderly, devout people who recognized the infant Jesus as the Messiah when he was presented in the Temple (Luke 2)?
verseText: Now there was a man in Jerusalem, whose name was Simeon... And there was a prophetess, Anna, the daughter of Phanuel...

text: What event from Jesus' childhood is uniquely recorded in Luke 2, when he was 12 years old?
options: His visit to the Temple in Jerusalem, where he stayed behind and conversed with the teachers
verseText: Now his parents went to Jerusalem every year at the Feast of the Passover. And when he was twelve years old, they went up according to custom... After three days they found him in the temple, sitting among the teachers, listening to them and asking them questions.

text: In Luke 4, Jesus reads from which prophet in the synagogue at Nazareth, applying the prophecy to himself?
verseText: And the scroll of the prophet Isaiah was given to him. He unrolled the scroll and found the place where it was written, “The Spirit of the Lord is upon me, because he has anointed me to proclaim good news to the poor...” And he began to say to them, “Today this Scripture has been fulfilled in your hearing.”

text: What was the reaction of the people in Nazareth after Jesus applied the prophecy from Isaiah to himself (Luke 4)?
options: They were filled with wrath and tried to throw him off a cliff
verseText: When they heard these things, all in the synagogue were filled with wrath. And they rose up and drove him out of the town and brought him to the brow of the hill on which their town was built, so that they could throw him down the cliff.

text: What miracle involving fish did Jesus perform before calling Simon Peter, James, and John (Luke 5)?
options: Walking on water to the fishing boat
Commanding a miraculous catch of fish that filled two boats
Calming a storm while they were fishing
verseText: And when he had finished speaking, he said to Simon, “Put out into the deep and let down your nets for a catch.”... And when they had done this, they enclosed a large number of fish, and their nets were breaking. They signaled to their partners in the other boat to come and help them. And they came and filled both the boats, so that they began to sink.

text: What was Simon Peter's reaction to the miraculous catch of fish (Luke 5)?
options: He fell down at Jesus' knees, saying, 'Depart from me, for I am a sinful man, O Lord.'
He asked Jesus how he did it
He immediately started selling the fish
verseText: But when Simon Peter saw it, he fell down at Jesus' knees, saying, “Depart from me, for I am a sinful man, O Lord.”

text: Luke's version of the Beatitudes (Luke 6) includes corresponding 'Woes'. For example, 'Blessed are you who are poor' is contrasted with...
options: 'Woe to you when all people speak well of you'
verseText: And he lifted up his eyes on his disciples, and said: “Blessed are you who are poor, for yours is the kingdom of God... But woe to you who are rich, for you have received your consolation.

text: Which miracle, unique to Luke, involves Jesus raising a widow's only son from the dead in the town of Nain (Luke 7)?
options: Raising the widow's son at Nain
verseText: As he drew near to the gate of the town, behold, a man who had died was being carried out, the only son of his mother, and she was a widow... And he touched the bier, and the bearers stood still. And he said, “Young man, I say to you, arise.” And the dead man sat up and began to speak, and Jesus gave him to his mother.

text: Who anointed Jesus' feet with tears and ointment in the house of Simon the Pharisee (Luke 7)?
options: A woman of the city, who was a sinner
verseText: And behold, a woman of the city, who was a sinner, when she learned that he was reclining at table in the Pharisee's house, brought an alabaster flask of ointment, and standing behind him at his feet, weeping, she began to wet his feet with her tears and wiped them with the hair of her head and kissed his feet and anointed them with the ointment.

text: Luke 8 mentions several women who supported Jesus' ministry out of their own means. Who are specifically named?
options: Mary Magdalene, Joanna, Susanna, and many others
verseText: and also some women who had been healed of evil spirits and infirmities: Mary, called Magdalene, from whom seven demons had gone out, and Joanna, the wife of Chuza, Herod's household manager, and Susanna, and many others, who provided for them out of their means.

text: When James and John wanted to call down fire on a Samaritan village that rejected Jesus, what was Jesus' response (Luke 9)?
verseText: And when his disciples James and John saw it, they said, “Lord, do you want us to tell fire to come down from heaven and consume them?” But he turned and rebuked them. And they went on to another village.

text: How many disciples did Jesus send out in pairs ahead of him in Luke 10 (distinct from the Twelve)?
verseText: After this the Lord appointed seventy-two others and sent them on ahead of him, two by two, into every town and place where he himself was about to go.

text: In the story of Mary and Martha (Luke 10), what did Jesus say Mary had chosen?
options: The better part (listening to his teaching)
verseText: But the Lord answered her, “Martha, Martha, you are anxious and troubled about many things, but one thing is necessary. Mary has chosen the good portion, which will not be taken away from her.”

text: Luke's version of the Lord's Prayer (Luke 11) is shorter than Matthew's. It begins simply with...
verseText: And he said to them, “When you pray, say: “Father, hallowed be your name. Your kingdom come.

text: Which parable, unique to Luke, warns against greed and storing up earthly treasures (Luke 12)?
options: The Parable of the Rich Fool
The Parable of the Lost Sheep
The Parable of the Ten Virgins
verseText: And he told them a parable, saying, “The land of a rich man produced plentifully... But God said to him, ‘Fool! This night your soul is required of you, and the things you have prepared, whose will they be?’ So is the one who lays up treasure for himself and is not rich toward God.”

text: In Luke 13, Jesus tells a parable about a fig tree that bore no fruit. What did the owner want to do, and what did the vinedresser suggest?
options: Cut it down / Give it one more year with fertilizer
verseText: And he told this parable: “A man had a fig tree planted in his vineyard, and he came seeking fruit on it and found none. And he said to the vinedresser, ‘Look, for three years now I have come seeking fruit on this fig tree, and I find none. Cut it down...’ And he answered him, ‘Sir, let it alone this year also, until I dig around it and put on manure. Then if it should bear fruit next year, well and good; but if not, you can cut it down.’”

text: Which parable unique to Luke describes guests making excuses for not attending a great banquet (Luke 14)?
options: The Parable of the Wedding Feast
The Parable of the Great Banquet
The Parable of the Ten Virgins
verseText: But he said to him, “A man once gave a great banquet and invited many. And at the time for the banquet he sent his servant to say to those who had been invited, ‘Come, for everything is now ready.’ But they all alike began to make excuses...

text: Luke 15 contains three parables about finding something lost. What are they?
options: Lost Son, Lost Coin, Lost Time
Lost Sheep, Lost Coin, Lost (Prodigal) Son
Lost Opportunity, Lost Friend, Lost Hope
Lost Key, Lost Scroll, Lost Path
verseText: “What man of you, having a hundred sheep, if he has lost one of them... Or what woman, having ten silver coins, if she loses one coin... And he said, “There was a man who had two sons...

text: Which parable, unique to Luke, tells of a shrewd manager who reduces debts owed to his master (Luke 16)?
options: The Parable of the Unjust Steward
The Parable of the Rich Fool
The Parable of the Workers in the Vineyard
verseText: He also said to the disciples, “There was a rich man who had a manager, and charges were brought to him that this man was wasting his possessions... The master commended the dishonest manager for his shrewdness.

text: Which parable, unique to Luke, describes the afterlife fates of a poor man and a wealthy man (Luke 16)?
options: The Parable of the Sheep and Goats
The Parable of the Rich Man and Lazarus
The Parable of the Ten Virgins
verseText: “There was a rich man who was clothed in purple and fine linen and who feasted sumptuously every day. And at his gate was laid a poor man named Lazarus, covered with sores...

text: Out of ten lepers healed by Jesus in Luke 17, how many returned to thank him?
verseText: Then one of them, when he saw that he was healed, turned back, praising God with a loud voice; and he fell on his face at Jesus' feet, giving him thanks. Now he was a Samaritan.

text: Which parable, unique to Luke, contrasts the prayers of a Pharisee and a tax collector in the temple (Luke 18)?
options: The Parable of the Persistent Widow
The Parable of the Pharisee and the Tax Collector
The Parable of the Friend at Midnight
The Parable of the Good Samaritan
verseText: “Two men went up into the temple to pray, one a Pharisee and the other a tax collector. The Pharisee, standing by himself, prayed thus... But the tax collector, standing far off, would not even lift up his eyes to heaven, but beat his breast, saying, ‘God, be merciful to me, a sinner!’

text: Who was the short tax collector who climbed a sycamore tree to see Jesus and later hosted him (Luke 19)?
verseText: And behold, there was a man named Zacchaeus. He was a chief tax collector and was rich. And he was seeking to see who Jesus was, but on account of the crowd he could not, because he was small in stature. So he ran on ahead and climbed up into a sycamore tree to see him... And when Jesus came to the place, he looked up and said to him, “Zacchaeus, hurry and come down, for I must stay at your house today.”

text: What did Zacchaeus promise to do after encountering Jesus (Luke 19)?
options: Give half his possessions to the poor and repay anyone he cheated fourfold
verseText: And Zacchaeus stood and said to the Lord, “Behold, Lord, the half of my goods I give to the poor. And if I have defrauded anyone of anything, I restore it fourfold.”

text: What emotion did Jesus express as he approached Jerusalem and wept over the city (Luke 19)?
verseText: And when he drew near and saw the city, he wept over it, saying, “Would that you, even you, had known on this day the things that make for peace! But now they are hidden from your eyes.

text: In Luke's account of the Garden of Gethsemane, what detail is mentioned about Jesus' intense prayer (Luke 22)?
options: An angel strengthened him and his sweat became like great drops of blood
verseText: And there appeared to him an angel from heaven, strengthening him. And being in an agony he prayed more earnestly; and his sweat became like great drops of blood falling down to the ground.

text: Besides Pilate, before which other ruler was Jesus sent during his trial, according to Luke 23?
verseText: And when he learned that he belonged to Herod's jurisdiction, he sent him over to Herod, who was himself in Jerusalem at that time.

text: What did Jesus say from the cross regarding his persecutors, according to Luke 23?
options: 'Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do.'
verseText: And Jesus said, “Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do.”

text: What promise did Jesus make to one of the criminals crucified with him (Luke 23)?
options: 'Truly, I say to you, today you will be with me in Paradise.'
verseText: And he said, “Jesus, remember me when you come into your kingdom.” And he said to him, “Truly, I say to you, today you will be with me in Paradise.”

text: What were the disciples on the road to Emmaus discussing when Jesus joined them (Luke 24)?
options: The recent events concerning Jesus' crucifixion and reports of his resurrection
verseText: And they were talking with each other about all these things that had happened... And he said to them, “What things?” And they said to him, “Concerning Jesus of Nazareth, a man who was a prophet mighty in deed and word before God and all the people...

text: When did the disciples on the road to Emmaus recognize Jesus (Luke 24)?
options: When he broke bread with them
When he showed them his hands
When he called them by name
verseText: When he was at table with them, he took the bread and blessed and broke it and gave it to them. And their eyes were opened, and they recognized him. And he vanished from their sight.

text: What did Jesus instruct his disciples to wait for in Jerusalem before his ascension (Luke 24)?
options: The promise of the Father (power from on high/Holy Spirit)
verseText: And behold, I am sending the promise of my Father upon you. But stay in the city until you are clothed with power from on high.”

text: How does the Gospel of Luke end?
options: With the disciples hiding in fear
With Jesus' ascension into heaven and the disciples worshiping and returning to Jerusalem with joy
verseText: While he blessed them, he parted from them and was carried up into heaven. And they worshiped him and returned to Jerusalem with great joy, and were continually in the temple blessing God.

text: What specific advice did John the Baptist give to tax collectors who came to be baptized?
options: Collect no more than you are authorized to
Give half your money to the poor
verseText: Tax collectors also came to be baptized and said to him, “Teacher, what shall we do?” And he said to them, “Collect no more than you are authorized to do.”

text: What specific advice did John the Baptist give to soldiers who came to be baptized?
options: Do not extort money, accuse falsely, and be content with your wages
verseText: Soldiers also asked him, “And we, what shall we do?” And he said to them, “Do not extort money from anyone by threats or by false accusation, and be content with your wages.”

text: In Luke's account of the temptation, the devil takes Jesus to a high mountain and offers him what in exchange for worship?
options: All the food he could eat
All the kingdoms of the world and their glory
verseText: And the devil took him up and showed him all the kingdoms of the world in a moment of time, and said to him, “To you I will give all this authority and their glory... if you, then, will worship me, it will all be yours.”

text: After Jesus called Levi (Matthew) the tax collector, Levi held a great feast. Who attended this feast, causing the Pharisees to grumble?
options: A large company of tax collectors and others
verseText: And Levi made him a great feast in his house, and there was a large company of tax collectors and others reclining at table with them. And the Pharisees and their scribes grumbled at his disciples, saying, “Why do you eat and drink with tax collectors and sinners?”

text: In the Sermon on the Plain (Luke 6), Jesus says, 'Love your enemies, do good to those who hate you, bless those who curse you, ...'
verseText: “But I say to you who hear, Love your enemies, do good to those who hate you, bless those who curse you, pray for those who abuse you.

text: What specific action does Jesus command regarding how we treat others' possessions in the Sermon on the Plain?
options: If someone takes your cloak, offer your tunic also
verseText: To one who strikes you on the cheek, offer the other also, and from one who takes away your cloak do not withhold your tunic either.

text: What standard does Jesus set for judging others in Luke 6?
options: Judge only those outside the faith
'Judge not, and you will not be judged; condemn not, and you will not be condemned'
verseText: “Judge not, and you will not be judged; condemn not, and you will not be condemned; forgive, and you will be forgiven;

text: When healing the centurion's servant (Luke 7), what message did the centurion send that showed his great faith and understanding of authority?
options: He asked Jesus to come quickly
He said he was unworthy for Jesus to enter his house, asking Jesus to just say the word
verseText: the centurion sent friends, saying to him, “Lord, do not trouble yourself, for I am not worthy to have you come under my roof. Therefore I did not presume to come to you. But say the word, and let my servant be healed. For I too am a man set under authority...

text: In the Parable of the Sower (Luke 8), what does the seed that fell among thorns represent?
options: Those who hear but don't understand
Those who hear with joy but have no root
Those who hear, but are choked by the cares, riches, and pleasures of life
Those who hear, hold fast, and bear fruit
verseText: And as for what fell among the thorns, they are those who hear, but as they go on their way they are choked by the cares and riches and pleasures of life, and their fruit does not mature.

text: What does Jesus say about a lamp after it is lit (Luke 8)?
options: It is put on a stand so that those who enter may see the light
It should only be used at night
verseText: “No one after lighting a lamp covers it with a jar or puts it under a bed, but puts it on a stand, so that those who enter may see the light.

text: When someone wanted to follow Jesus but first say farewell to his family, Jesus replied, 'No one who puts his hand to the plow and looks back is...'
verseText: Yet another said, “I will follow you, Lord, but let me first say farewell to those at my home.” Jesus said to him, “No one who puts his hand to the plow and looks back is fit for the kingdom of God.”

text: When the seventy-two disciples returned rejoicing that demons were subject to them, what did Jesus say they should rejoice about instead?
options: That their names are written in heaven
verseText: The seventy-two returned with joy, saying, “Lord, even the demons are subject to us in your name!”... Nevertheless, do not rejoice in this, that the spirits are subject to you, but rejoice that your names are written in heaven.”

text: In Luke 11, Jesus tells a parable to encourage persistent prayer. What does the man in the parable ask his neighbor for at midnight?
verseText: And he said to them, “Which of you who has a friend will go to him at midnight and say to him, ‘Friend, lend me three loaves, for a friend of mine has arrived on a journey, and I have nothing to set before him’?

text: Jesus pronounced 'Woes' upon the Pharisees for tithing herbs while neglecting what?
options: Justice and the love of God
verseText: “But woe to you Pharisees! For you tithe mint and rue and every herb, and neglect justice and the love of God. These you ought to have done, without neglecting the others.

text: Jesus pronounced 'Woes' upon the lawyers (experts in the law) for what reason related to 'burdens' and the 'key of knowledge'?
options: They loaded people with burdens hard to bear but didn't lift a finger, and took away the key of knowledge
verseText: And he said, “Woe to you lawyers also! For you load people with burdens hard to bear, and you yourselves do not touch the burdens with one of your fingers... Woe to you lawyers! For you have taken away the key of knowledge. You did not enter yourselves, and you hindered those who were entering.”

text: Jesus warned his disciples to beware of the 'leaven' of the Pharisees, which he identified as what?
verseText: In the meantime, when so many thousands of the people had gathered together that they were trampling one another, he began to say to his disciples first, “Beware of the leaven of the Pharisees, which is hypocrisy.

text: Whom did Jesus say we should fear?
options: Those who can kill the body
The one who, after killing, has authority to cast into hell (God)
verseText: “I tell you, my friends, do not fear those who kill the body, and after that have nothing more that they can do. But I will warn you whom to fear: fear him who, after he has killed, has authority to cast into hell. Yes, I tell you, fear him!

text: What did Jesus say about acknowledging or denying him before men?
options: It doesn't matter what people think
Whoever acknowledges him before men, the Son of Man will acknowledge before God's angels; whoever denies him will be denied
verseText: “And I tell you, everyone who acknowledges me before men, the Son of Man also will acknowledge before the angels of God, but the one who denies me before men will be denied before the angels of God.

text: Jesus spoke about the unforgivable sin against whom?
verseText: And everyone who speaks a word against the Son of Man will be forgiven, but the one who blasphemes against the Holy Spirit will not be forgiven.

text: When told about Galileans killed by Pilate and people killed by the tower of Siloam, what did Jesus say was necessary to avoid perishing?
verseText: No, I tell you; but unless you repent, you will all likewise perish... No, I tell you; but unless you repent, you will all likewise perish.”

text: Jesus healed a woman crippled for 18 years on the Sabbath (Luke 13). How did he respond to the synagogue ruler's indignation?
options: He apologized for breaking the rule
He called them hypocrites for untying animals on the Sabbath, arguing the woman deserved release
verseText: Then the Lord answered him, “You hypocrites! Does not each of you on the Sabbath untie his ox or his donkey from the manger and lead it away to water it? And ought not this woman, a daughter of Abraham whom Satan bound for eighteen years, be loosed from this bond on the Sabbath day?”

text: In Luke 14, Jesus healed a man with dropsy on the Sabbath. What question did he ask the lawyers and Pharisees before healing him?
options: 'Is it lawful to heal on the Sabbath, or not?'
'Who sinned, this man or his parents?'
'Do you believe I can do this?'
verseText: And Jesus responded to the lawyers and Pharisees, saying, “Is it lawful to heal on the Sabbath, or not?”

text: Observing guests choosing places of honor, Jesus taught about humility. What advice did he give regarding seating at a wedding feast?
options: Take the lowest place, so you might be invited higher
verseText: “When you are invited by someone to a wedding feast, do not sit down in a place of honor... But when you are invited, go and sit in the lowest place, so that when your host comes he may say to you, ‘Friend, move up higher.’ Then you will be honored in the presence of all who sit at table with you.

text: Who did Jesus advise people to invite to their feasts, promising repayment at the resurrection of the just (Luke 14)?
options: The poor, crippled, lame, and blind
verseText: He said also to the man who had invited him, “When you give a dinner or a banquet, do not invite your friends or your brothers or your relatives or rich neighbors... But when you give a feast, invite the poor, the crippled, the lame, the blind, and you will be blessed, because they cannot repay you. For you will be repaid at the resurrection of the just.”

text: What cost of discipleship did Jesus emphasize, involving hating family and carrying one's cross (Luke 14)?
options: Absolute commitment to Jesus above all else
verseText: “If anyone comes to me and does not hate his own father and mother and wife and children and brothers and sisters, yes, and even his own life, he cannot be my disciple. Whoever does not bear his own cross and come after me cannot be my disciple.

text: In the Parable of the Lost Coin (Luke 15), what does the woman do when she finds the coin?
options: Calls her friends and neighbors to rejoice with her
verseText: And when she has found it, she calls together her friends and neighbors, saying, ‘Rejoice with me, for I have found the coin that I had lost.’

text: What saying follows the Parable of the Unjust Steward regarding serving two masters (Luke 16)?
options: 'A worker is worthy of his wages'
'No servant can serve two masters... You cannot serve God and money (mammon).'
'The love of money is a root of all kinds of evil'
verseText: No servant can serve two masters, for either he will hate the one and love the other, or he will be devoted to the one and despise the other. You cannot serve God and money.”

text: Regarding forgiveness, Jesus told his disciples, 'If your brother sins, rebuke him, and if he repents, forgive him, and if he sins against you...' how many times in a day?
verseText: Pay attention to yourselves! If your brother sins, rebuke him, and if he repents, forgive him, and if he sins against you seven times in the day, and turns to you seven times, saying, ‘I repent,’ you must forgive him.”

text: When the apostles asked Jesus to increase their faith, what did Jesus say faith like a grain of mustard seed could do?
options: Command a mulberry tree to be uprooted and planted in the sea
verseText: And the Lord said, “If you had faith like a grain of mustard seed, you could say to this mulberry tree, ‘Be uprooted and planted in the sea,’ and it would obey you.

text: Jesus told the Parable of the Persistent Widow and the Unjust Judge (Luke 18) to teach his disciples what?
options: That they should always pray and not lose heart
verseText: And he told them a parable to the effect that they ought always to pray and not lose heart.

text: Jesus told the Parable of the Minas (Pounds) (Luke 19) because he was near Jerusalem and people thought what would happen immediately?
options: The kingdom of God was to appear immediately
verseText: As they heard these things, he proceeded to tell a parable, because he was near to Jerusalem, and because they supposed that the kingdom of God was to appear immediately.

text: In the Parable of the Minas (Luke 19), what happened to the servant who hid his mina in a cloth?
options: He was praised for being careful
His mina was taken away and given to the one who had ten
verseText: Then another came, saying, ‘Lord, here is your mina, which I kept laid away in a handkerchief...’ ...And he said to those who stood by, ‘Take the mina from him, and give it to the one who has the ten minas.’

text: In Luke's account of the Sadducees' question about the resurrection (Luke 20), Jesus emphasizes that resurrected people are like angels and are what?
options: Children of God, being children of the resurrection
verseText: but those who are considered worthy to attain to that age and to the resurrection from the dead neither marry nor are given in marriage, for they cannot die anymore, because they are equal to angels and are children of God, being children of the resurrection.

text: In Luke's version of the Olivet Discourse (Luke 21), what specific sign involving Jerusalem does Jesus mention preceding its desolation?
verseText: “But when you see Jerusalem surrounded by armies, then know that its desolation has come near.

text: During the Last Supper, after predicting Peter's denial, what did Jesus tell Peter he should do once he had turned back?
verseText: “Simon, Simon, behold, Satan demanded to have you, that he might sift you like wheat, but I have prayed for you that your faith may not fail. And when you have turned again, strengthen your brothers.”

text: What did Jesus instruct his disciples to buy if they didn't have one, right before going to Gethsemane (Luke 22)?
verseText: He said to them, “But now let the one who has a moneybag take it, and likewise a knapsack. And let the one who has no sword sell his cloak and buy one.

text: As Jesus was being led away to be crucified, he spoke to women who were mourning. What did he tell them (Luke 23)?
options: To weep for themselves and their children because of coming judgment
verseText: But Jesus turning to them said, “Daughters of Jerusalem, do not weep for me, but weep for yourselves and for your children. For behold, the days are coming when they will say, ‘Blessed are the barren and the wombs that never bore and the breasts that never nursed!’

text: When the resurrected Jesus appeared to the disciples in Jerusalem (Luke 24), what did he do to prove he wasn't a spirit?
options: Showed them his hands and feet and ate a piece of broiled fish
verseText: And he said to them, “Why are you troubled, and why do doubts arise in your hearts? See my hands and my feet, that it is I myself. Touch me, and see. For a spirit does not have flesh and bones as you see that I have.”... They gave him a piece of broiled fish, and he took it and ate before them.

text: Before ascending, Jesus opened the disciples' minds to understand the Scriptures, stating that the Christ must suffer, rise on the third day, and what must be proclaimed in his name?
options: Repentance and forgiveness of sins to all nations
The establishment of an earthly kingdom
verseText: Then he opened their minds to understand the Scriptures, and said to them, “Thus it is written, that the Christ should suffer and on the third day rise from the dead, and that repentance and forgiveness of sins should be proclaimed in his name to all nations, beginning from Jerusalem.

text: What occupation is traditionally associated with Luke, the author of the Gospel?
verseText: Luke the beloved physician greets you, as does Demas.

text: What did the angel Gabriel tell Mary her son Jesus would be called?
verseText: He will be great and will be called the Son of the Most High. And the Lord God will give to him the throne of his father David,

text: How did Mary respond to the angel Gabriel's announcement?
options: 'Behold, I am the servant of the Lord; let it be to me according to your word.'
verseText: And Mary said, “Behold, I am the servant of the Lord; let it be to me according to your word.” And the angel departed from her.

text: When Mary visited Elizabeth, what happened to Elizabeth's baby (John the Baptist)?
verseText: And when Elizabeth heard the greeting of Mary, the baby leaped in her womb. And Elizabeth was filled with the Holy Spirit,

text: In Mary's Magnificat, she praises God for scattering the proud and bringing down whom from their thrones?
verseText: He has shown strength with his arm; he has scattered the proud in the thoughts of their hearts; he has brought down the mighty from their thrones and exalted those of humble estate;

text: According to Zechariah's Benedictus, what role would his son John play?
options: Prophet of the Most High, preparing the Lord's ways
verseText: And you, child, will be called the prophet of the Most High; for you will go before the Lord to prepare his ways,

text: What was the essence of the angels' message to the shepherds?
options: Good news of great joy: a Savior, Christ the Lord, is born
verseText: And the angel said to them, “Fear not, for behold, I bring you good news of great joy that will be for all the people. For unto you is born this day in the city of David a Savior, who is Christ the Lord.

text: What sign did the angel give the shepherds to identify the newborn Savior?
options: A baby wrapped in swaddling cloths and lying in a manger
verseText: And this will be a sign for you: you will find a baby wrapped in swaddling cloths and lying in a manger.”

text: What did Simeon prophesy about Jesus when he saw him in the temple?
options: He would be a great king
He was destined for the fall and rising of many in Israel, and to be a sign that is opposed
He would travel to distant lands
verseText: and Simeon blessed them and said to Mary his mother, “Behold, this child is appointed for the fall and rising of many in Israel, and for a sign that is opposed

text: What did Simeon prophesy would happen to Mary herself?
options: A sword would pierce through her own soul also
She would live a long life
verseText: (and a sword will pierce through your own soul also), so that thoughts from many hearts may be revealed.”

text: What did the prophetess Anna do when she saw the child Jesus in the temple?
options: She began to give thanks to God and spoke of him to all looking for redemption
verseText: And coming up at that very hour she began to give thanks to God and to speak of him to all who were waiting for the redemption of Jerusalem.

text: When Jesus' parents found him in the temple at age 12, what was his reply to their concern?
options: 'Why were you looking for me? Did you not know I must be in my Father's house?'
'I wanted to learn from the teachers.'
verseText: And he said to them, “Why were you looking for me? Did you not know that I must be in my Father's house?”

text: What did John the Baptist preach was necessary for the crowds coming for baptism?
options: Bearing fruits in keeping with repentance
verseText: Bear fruits in keeping with repentance. And do not begin to say to yourselves, ‘We have Abraham as our father.’ For I tell you, God is able from these stones to raise up children for Abraham.

text: What happened immediately after Jesus was baptized by John, according to Luke?
options: Heaven opened, the Holy Spirit descended like a dove, and a voice came from heaven
verseText: Now when all the people were baptized, and when Jesus also had been baptized and was praying, the heavens were opened, and the Holy Spirit descended on him in bodily form, like a dove; and a voice came from heaven, “You are my beloved Son; with you I am well pleased.”

text: In Luke's account, how long was Jesus tempted by the devil in the wilderness?
verseText: And Jesus, full of the Holy Spirit, returned from the Jordan and was led by the Spirit in the wilderness for forty days, being tempted by the devil.

text: After reading from Isaiah in Nazareth, Jesus mentioned which two Old Testament examples of God showing favor to Gentiles?
options: Naaman the Syrian and the widow of Zarephath
The Queen of Sheba and Hiram of Tyre
verseText: But in truth, I tell you, there were many widows in Israel in the days of Elijah... and Elijah was sent to none of them but only to Zarephath, in the land of Sidon, to a woman who was a widow. And there were many lepers in Israel in the time of the prophet Elisha, and none of them was cleansed, but only Naaman the Syrian.”

text: After healing Simon Peter's mother-in-law, what did Jesus do when the sun was setting?
options: He healed all who were sick with various diseases brought to him
verseText: Now when the sun was setting, all those who had any who were sick with various diseases brought them to him, and he laid his hands on every one of them and healed them.

text: When Jesus healed the paralytic lowered through the roof, what statement caused the scribes and Pharisees to accuse him of blasphemy?
verseText: And when he saw their faith, he said, “Man, your sins are forgiven you.” And the scribes and the Pharisees began to question, saying, “Who is this who speaks blasphemies? Who can forgive sins but God alone?”

text: In the Sermon on the Plain, Jesus uses the analogy of a tree and its fruit to illustrate what?
options: That a person's words and actions reveal their heart
verseText: “For no good tree bears bad fruit, nor again does a bad tree bear good fruit, for each tree is known by its own fruit... The good person out of the good treasure of his heart produces good, and the evil person out of his evil treasure produces evil, for out of the abundance of the heart his mouth speaks.

text: Jesus compares hearing his words and doing them to building a house on what foundation?
verseText: Everyone who comes to me and hears my words and does them, I will show you what he is like: he is like a man building a house, who dug deep and laid the foundation on the rock.

text: When John the Baptist sent disciples to ask Jesus, 'Are you the one who is to come?', how did Jesus answer?
options: He told them to report the miracles and preaching they saw and heard
verseText: In that hour he cured many of diseases and plagues and evil spirits, and on many who were blind he bestowed sight. And he answered them, “Go and tell John what you have seen and heard: the blind receive their sight, the lame walk, lepers are cleansed, and the deaf hear, the dead are raised up, the poor have good news preached to them.

text: Jesus contrasted John the Baptist's ascetic lifestyle with his own participation in meals, leading some to call Jesus what?
options: A glutton and a drunkard, a friend of tax collectors and sinners
verseText: For John the Baptist has come eating no bread and drinking no wine, and you say, ‘He has a demon.’ The Son of Man has come eating and drinking, and you say, ‘Look at him! A glutton and a drunkard, a friend of tax collectors and sinners!’

text: In the Parable of the Two Debtors (told to Simon the Pharisee), who loved the moneylender more?
options: The one forgiven a small debt
The one forgiven a large debt
verseText: “A certain moneylender had two debtors. One owed five hundred denarii, and the other fifty. When they could not pay, he cancelled the debt of both. Now which of them will love him more?” Simon answered, “The one, I suppose, for whom he cancelled the larger debt.”

text: When Jesus calmed the storm on the lake, what question did the terrified disciples ask each other?
options: 'Who then is this, that he commands even winds and water, and they obey him?'
verseText: He said to them, “Where is your faith?” And they were afraid, and they marveled, saying to one another, “Who then is this, that he commands even winds and water, and they obey him?”

text: After healing the Gerasene demoniac ('Legion'), what did the local people ask Jesus to do?
options: Depart from them, because they were afraid
verseText: Then all the people of the surrounding country of the Gerasenes asked him to depart from them, for they were seized with great fear. So he got into the boat and returned.

text: In Luke's account of the Transfiguration, what were Moses and Elijah talking with Jesus about?
options: His departure (exodus), which he was about to accomplish at Jerusalem
verseText: And behold, two men were talking with him, Moses and Elijah, who appeared in glory and spoke of his departure, which he was about to accomplish at Jerusalem.

text: What did Jesus say about the harvest and the laborers?
options: The harvest is small, and the laborers are many
The harvest is plentiful, but the laborers are few
The harvest is ready, but the laborers are unwilling
The harvest is difficult, and the laborers are weak
verseText: And he said to them, “The harvest is plentiful, but the laborers are few. Therefore pray earnestly to the Lord of the harvest to send out laborers into his harvest.

text: Jesus pronounced 'Woe' on which Galilean towns because they did not repent despite the mighty works done there?
verseText: “Woe to you, Chorazin! Woe to you, Bethsaida! For if the mighty works done in you had been done in Tyre and Sidon, they would have repented long ago, sitting in sackcloth and ashes.

text: Jesus rejoiced in the Holy Spirit and thanked the Father for hiding things from the wise and revealing them to whom?
verseText: In that same hour he rejoiced in the Holy Spirit and said, “I thank you, Father, Lord of heaven and earth, that you have hidden these things from the wise and understanding and revealed them to little children; yes, Father, for such was your gracious will.

text: Jesus taught, 'Ask, and it will be given to you; seek, and you will find; knock, and it will be opened to you.' This encourages what?
verseText: And I tell you, ask, and it will be given to you; seek, and you will find; knock, and it will be opened to you. For everyone who asks receives, and the one who seeks finds, and to the one who knocks it will be opened.

text: Jesus compared God's willingness to give the Holy Spirit to earthly fathers giving what to their children?
verseText: What father among you, if his son asks for a fish, will instead of a fish give him a serpent; or if he asks for an egg, will give him a scorpion? If you then, who are evil, know how to give good gifts to your children, how much more will the heavenly Father give the Holy Spirit to those who ask him!”

text: When accused of casting out demons by Beelzebul, Jesus warned that a kingdom divided against itself would face what consequence?
verseText: But he, knowing their thoughts, said to them, “Every kingdom divided against itself is laid waste, and a divided household falls.

text: Jesus said that when an unclean spirit goes out of a person and returns to find the 'house' swept and put in order, what might happen?
options: It brings seven other spirits more evil than itself, making the final state worse
The spirit asks permission to return
verseText: “When the unclean spirit has gone out of a person... Then it says, ‘I will return to my house from which I came.’ And when it comes, it finds the house swept and put in order. Then it goes and brings seven other spirits more evil than itself, and they enter and dwell there. And the last state of that person is worse than the first.”

text: When a woman in the crowd blessed Jesus' mother, how did Jesus redirect the blessing?
options: He said, 'Blessed rather are those who hear the word of God and keep it!'
He blessed the woman in return
verseText: As he said these things, a woman in the crowd raised her voice and said to him, “Blessed is the womb that bore you, and the breasts at which you nursed!” But he said, “Blessed rather are those who hear the word of God and keep it!”

text: Jesus spoke of the 'sign of Jonah'. What did he say this sign represented for 'this generation'?
options: Jonah himself (implicitly pointing to Jesus' death and resurrection)
verseText: When the crowds were increasing, he began to say, “This generation is an evil generation. It seeks for a sign, but no sign will be given to it except the sign of Jonah. For as Jonah became a sign to the people of Nineveh, so will the Son of Man be to this generation.

text: Jesus warned against anxiety about life, food, and clothing. What examples from nature did he use to illustrate God's provision?
verseText: Consider the ravens: they neither sow nor reap, they have neither storehouse nor barn, and yet God feeds them... Consider the lilies, how they grow: they neither toil nor spin, yet I tell you, even Solomon in all his glory was not arrayed like one of these.

text: Instead of worrying, what did Jesus tell his disciples to seek first?
verseText: Instead, seek his kingdom, and these things will be added to you.

text: Jesus told his disciples to be ready and keep their lamps burning, like servants waiting for what?
options: Their master to return from the wedding feast
verseText: “Stay dressed for action and keep your lamps burning, and be like men who are waiting for their master to come home from the wedding feast, so that they may open the door to him at once when he comes and knocks.

text: Jesus spoke of bringing division, even within families (father against son, mother against daughter). Why did he say he came?
options: To bring peace at all costs
To bring fire and division based on response to him
verseText: “I came to cast fire on the earth, and would that it were already kindled!... Do you think that I have come to give peace on earth? No, I tell you, but rather division. For from now on in one house there will be five divided, three against two and two against three...

text: In the Parable of the Great Banquet, after the invited guests made excuses, whom did the master tell the servant to invite?
options: The poor, crippled, blind, and lame from the streets and lanes
verseText: So the servant came and reported these things to his master. Then the master of the house became angry and said to his servant, ‘Go out quickly to the streets and lanes of the city, and bring in the poor and crippled and blind and lame.’

text: Jesus used the examples of building a tower and a king going to war to illustrate the need to do what before becoming a disciple?
verseText: For which of you, desiring to build a tower, does not first sit down and count the cost... Or what king, going out to encounter another king in war, will not sit down first and deliberate...

text: In the Parable of the Prodigal Son, what was the older brother's reaction when the younger son returned and was celebrated?
options: He became angry and refused to go in
He asked for his own feast
verseText: But he was angry and refused to go in. His father came out and entreated him,

text: In the story of the Rich Man and Lazarus, what did the rich man request from Abraham for his five brothers?
options: That Lazarus be sent back from the dead to warn them
That he himself could return to warn them
verseText: And he said, ‘Then I beg you, father, to send him to my father's house— for I have five brothers—so that he may warn them, lest they also come into this place of torment.’

text: What was Abraham's reply to the rich man's request to send Lazarus back to warn his brothers?
options: 'They have Moses and the Prophets; let them hear them.'
verseText: Abraham said, ‘They have Moses and the Prophets; let them hear them.’

text: Jesus warned about causing 'little ones' to stumble (sin). What did he say would be better than causing this?
options: Having a millstone hung around one's neck and being cast into the sea
verseText: And he said to his disciples, “Temptations to sin are sure to come, but woe to the one through whom they come! It would be better for him if a millstone were hung around his neck and he were cast into the sea than that he should cause one of these little ones to sin.

text: Jesus told a parable about an unworthy servant who simply does his duty. What attitude should the servant have?
options: Say, 'We are unworthy servants; we have only done what was our duty.'
verseText: Does he thank the servant because he did what was commanded? So you also, when you have done all that you were commanded, say, ‘We are unworthy servants; we have only done what was our duty.’”

text: When asked by the Pharisees when the kingdom of God would come, Jesus said the kingdom does not come with observation, but is where?
options: In the midst of you (or within you)
verseText: Being asked by the Pharisees when the kingdom of God would come, he answered them, “The kingdom of God is not coming in ways that can be observed, nor will they say, ‘Look, here it is!’ or ‘There!’ for behold, the kingdom of God is in the midst of you.”

text: Jesus compared the days of the Son of Man to the days of Noah and Lot. What were people doing before disaster struck?
options: Engaged in ordinary life: eating, drinking, marrying, buying, selling, planting, building
verseText: Just as it was in the days of Noah, so will it be in the days of the Son of Man. They were eating and drinking and marrying and being given in marriage, until the day when Noah entered the ark... Likewise, just as it was in the days of Lot—they were eating and drinking, buying and selling, planting and building...

text: What happened to Lot's wife when she looked back?
options: She became a pillar of salt
verseText: Remember Lot's wife.

text: In the Parable of the Pharisee and the Tax Collector, what did the tax collector pray?
options: 'Thank you God I am not like other men.'
'God, be merciful to me, a sinner!'
verseText: But the tax collector, standing far off, would not even lift up his eyes to heaven, but beat his breast, saying, ‘God, be merciful to me, a sinner!’

text: Who did Jesus say went home justified after praying in the temple: the Pharisee or the tax collector?
verseText: I tell you, this man went down to his house justified, rather than the other. For everyone who exalts himself will be humbled, but the one who humbles himself will be exalted.”

text: What did Jesus say about his purpose in coming, related to Zacchaeus?
options: The Son of Man came to seek and to save the lost
verseText: For the Son of Man came to seek and to save the lost.”

text: After cleansing the temple, what did Jesus do there daily?
verseText: And he was teaching daily in the temple. The chief priests and the scribes and the principal men of the people were seeking to destroy him,

text: In the Parable of the Wicked Tenants (Luke 20), what did the owner of the vineyard finally do after the tenants killed his son?
options: He will come and destroy those tenants and give the vineyard to others
verseText: And they threw him out of the vineyard and killed him. What then will the owner of the vineyard do to them? He will come and destroy those tenants and give the vineyard to others.”

text: Jesus warned his disciples about the end times, saying they would be brought before kings and governors for his name's sake. What opportunity would this provide?
verseText: But before all this they will lay their hands on you and persecute you, delivering you up to the synagogues and prisons, and you will be brought before kings and governors for my name's sake. This will be your opportunity to bear witness.

text: What did Jesus promise his disciples regarding their defense when persecuted?
options: He would give them a mouth and wisdom that opponents could not withstand
verseText: Settle it therefore in your minds not to meditate beforehand how to answer, for I will give you a mouth and wisdom, which none of your adversaries will be able to withstand or contradict.

text: Jesus said that by what means would the disciples gain their lives/souls during the tribulations?
verseText: By your endurance you will gain your lives.

text: What entered Judas Iscariot, leading him to betray Jesus?
verseText: Then Satan entered into Judas called Iscariot, who was of the number of the twelve.

text: During the Last Supper, Jesus told the disciples that the greatest among them should be like whom?
options: The youngest, and the leader like one who serves
verseText: But not so with you. Rather, let the greatest among you become as the youngest, and the leader as one who serves.

text: What was Herod Antipas's reaction when Jesus was sent to him?
options: He was glad, hoping to see a sign, questioned him, then mocked him
verseText: When Herod saw Jesus, he was very glad, for he had long desired to see him... hoping to see some sign done by him. So he questioned him at some length, but he made no answer... And Herod with his soldiers treated him with contempt and mocked him.

text: What did the centurion at the cross say after witnessing Jesus' death?
options: 'Truly this was the Son of God!' (cf. Mark)
'He saved others, himself he cannot save.'
verseText: Now when the centurion saw what had taken place, he praised God, saying, “Certainly this man was innocent!”
